content: The Act may be cited as "The Peter J. McGuire Labor Day Landmark Act". It includes findings related to labor. Peter J. McGuire played a significant role in the formation of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America in 1888. He was elected as the first general secretary and was instrumental in advocating for a national labor federation in the United States. McGuire also co-founded the Federation of Organized Trades and Labor Unions with Samuel Gompers in 1886. Peter J. McGuire was a key figure in the labor movement, helping to form the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America in 1888. He played a role in creating the American Federation of Labor in 1886 and led the fight for the eight-hour workday in 1890. McGuire also proposed the idea of Labor Day, which was later established as a national holiday in 1894. Upon his death in 1906, a large headstone was erected at his gravesite in Arlington Cemetery. The Peter J. McGuire Memorial in Pennsauken, New Jersey, was completed in 1952 to honor McGuire's legacy in the labor movement. Labor leaders, political leaders, and working people gather at his gravesite on Labor Day to pay tribute to his contributions. The memorial features a statue of McGuire surrounded by marble columns. The Peter J. McGuire Memorial in Pennsauken, New Jersey, completed in 1952, features a statue of McGuire surrounded by a curvilinear colonnade of Greek Doric columns made of Cherokee Georgia marble. The memorial includes inscriptions honoring McGuire as the founder of UBC and Father of Labor Day, erected by the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America in 1952. Several thousand people, including union members, attended the Peter J. McGuire Memorial dedication ceremony in 1952. Speakers at the event included the president of the New Jersey Federation of Labor, mayors of Camden and Pennsauken, General President Hutcheson of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners, President William Green and Secretary George Meany of the American Federation of Labor, and the United States Secretary of Labor, Maurice Tobin. In 1956, President Dwight Eisenhower honored Peter J. McGuire during a ceremony for a new postage stamp dedicated to American labor. McGuire was later admitted to the Labor Hall of Fame in 2004, now known as the Hall of Honor. The New Jersey Historic Preservation Office recognizes McGuire's national significance in labor history. The Peter J. McGuire Memorial and Gravesite reflect integrity in design and materials. The Peter J. McGuire Memorial and Gravesite, with sculptural representations of labor and union themes, are well-preserved. National political and labor leaders visit annually since 1906. These properties are unique for their direct association with McGuire and integrity for listing on the New Jersey Historic Preservation Office. The Peter J. McGuire Memorial and Gravesite meet the criteria for listing on the New Jersey Register of Historic Places and National Register of Historic Places as a grave of a historical figure and a property of exceptional significance. In August 2017, the New Jersey State Historic Preservation Office certified that the Peter J. McGuire Memorial and Gravesite are eligible for listing on the New Jersey Register of Historic Places and National Register of Historic Places. The Peter J. McGuire Memorial and Gravesite are eligible for listing on the New Jersey Register of Historic Places and National Register of Historic Places. Additionally, the designation of Peter J. McGuire Memorial as a National Historic Landmark is secured. The Peter J. McGuire Memorial and Gravesite in Pennsauken, New Jersey are designated as the Peter J. McGuire Memorial National Historic Landmark. The United States is not responsible for its maintenance. The Secretary can enter cooperative agreements for educational programs and provide assistance to entities involved. Designation of the Peter J. McGuire Memorial National Historic Landmark will not restrict property owners, including the owners of the landmark, from taking actions on their property.
